newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila says new taxes to be finalised by year-end.
newsitem.headline: Manila says new taxes to be finalised by year-end.

text.p: The Philippine government was optimistic its new tax package aimed at replacing a complicated system that has been widely abused would be finalised by year-end, a senior official said.
"We are optimistic that the comprehensive tax reform package will pass, the final version should come through by end of the year," finance secretary Roberto de Ocampo told reporters late on Monday.
The new tax package is crucial to the government's economic reform programme because it is designed to ensure a sustainable source of revenue.
But its implementation has been delayed in the legislature because of differing opinions over how beer and cigarettes should be taxed.
De Ocampo told reporters the tax reform package was one of the most important tasks before the government to ensure the benefits of economic reforms were sustained.
It was important because the Philippines had the lowest tax collection rate among East Asian countries, he said.
Philippine revenue from taxes amount to just about 16 percent of gross national product compared to over 20 percent for some other countries in the region.
A Department of Finance official said national statistics showed at least seven million people should have been paying income tax but actually only some 2.6 million people pay.
About 200,000 firms are registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission of which only 70,000 file returns and of these an even smaller segment pays tax.
The tax reform package includes three parts. The first, on oil products, has already been approved. The second, on beer and cigarette taxes, is still pending in the legislature.
The third part of the package is individual taxes which the government hopes to finalise next year.
